So this programme is misleading !!!

Note: It is impossible to take a "photo" of a Black Hole or anything for that matter, in a Galaxy Billions of Light Years away, as we can only just see that Galaxy ! The picture used is in fact and artists rendition based of the detection methods used. But intriguingly the picture shown is NOT a Black Hole but a Plasmoid (a huge electrical feature common in most galaxies).

If the black hole is not perceived as a 3D model, but its entirety laid out and seen as if 2D from the perspective of a viewer. We can apply that -1 dimension to a scale higher than us, 4D, and apply the same rule if our universe is a black hole (the black hole universe theory). Which would mean that time as a dimension is lost outside the event horizon from the perspective of those on the inside. What this means, is that if a black hole creates a new universe inside it (repeat indefinitely), it is effectively channeling time as a dimension through infinite perpetual layers of universes. Basically, the universe is a tunnel that feeds off its own self and sheds it. Like an ouroboros. Our computer monitors shows 3D from 2D, black holes show 2D from 3D. If black holes lose a dimension much like our screen gives the illusion of gaining a dimension. We view our world as 3D being in 4D. Then maybe our own universe is also 2D, but 3D inside. By that I mean - our universe on the SMALLEST level appear 3D to us. But our universe as a WHOLE, on a GRAND SCALE, could be 2D if we zoomed out far enough. By zooming out even more the 2D universe could appear as a tiny dot, as 1D.

So to put it simply. It could be that existence is 1D, then 2D further in, then 3D, then 4D etc. Based on the viewpoint of the observer. Meaning that the more compressed - the more "advanced" everything gets. So that the least destructive base universe is the most static / safest / constant, while increasing room for change - including life - also comes at the cost of having less and less power to manipulate the layers before it. Think of the universe as a donut where the skin of the donut is constantly moving, but the backside is like a traffic cone. A tail if you will. The universe eats itself eternally to sustain itself. So time... time is the effect we get from an existence which has to move infinitely to self sustain.

Wrong concept ... 4:10 and 5:10 ... “light rays coming from the observer” .. leaving a light shadow at the back of event horizon ?!?
The reality is tht light from distant stars, at an angle physically behind the black hole and the observer ... will be visible to the observer.
2ndly, The accretion disc (light) may or may NOT be visible to the observer ... as the light from the accretion disc may NOT spread out 360 spherically for the observer to see.
3rdly, accretion disc, composed of hot gases, must be spinning around the black hole spherically ... unlike the icy n rocky particles spinning around Saturn on a plain. Therefore the inside of the accretion mustn’t be visible to the observer.
In other words, telescopes can neither observe the back of the event horizon or its light shadow nor can the telescopes observe the accretion disc.

Wouldn't the relativistic beaming/doppler effect be based not on whether the matter is moving towards us, but whether it is moving along the path by which those photons reach us?

For example a photon from the right side of the accretion disk that gets turned 90 degrees to come towards us should have the same brightness as one from the left side that gets turned 270 degrees to come towards us. Both were emitted in the same direction (or opposite direction) as the emitting matter is moving, but to us they should be indistinguishable.

Of course, the different sides will look different in aggregate because the bulk of the photons that reach us will be coming on more direct path with only minor bending.

If I understand correctly, photons can do multiple laps and still break free as long as they are outside the 1.5r radius, so given a close up view we should see bands of alternating brightness and color, with a theoretical perfect camera with infinite resolution we would see infinite bands, each dimmer than the last but with the same relative pattern as it approaches the edge of the shadow.

It's worth mentioning that the black hole they visualized was not Sagittarius A* (mistake at 1:30).

Also, I think you might be a little off on why the image looks the way it does. The accretion disc isn't exactly in a stable orbit. Matter appears to slow down and redden as it approaches the event horizon, so it doesn't matter that it's falling quickly, you're still going to see it. The reason the shadow is bigger than the hole is not related to the stable innermost orbit, it's actually due to the photon sphere. Let me explain.

Light from behind the black hole can't reach us if it slips within the photon sphere and is not reflected back by something, so everything behind the photon sphere looks black. That's the actual shadow the hole casts. However, matter falling into the photon sphere can still emit light that will reach us, because the light it emits is not travelling toward the black hole (it's aimed right at us), provided it has not yet slipped past the event horizon. So the black hole looks larger than it is because the photon sphere blocks all light from behind the hole, but matter falling in is still visible until it hits the true horizon.

Black hole explained, Imagine a pressure That permeates the entire universe, even before anything exist, Some called this pressure dark matter or the field but the original name was the Aether, Now imagine 2 physical objects some distance apart from each other within this pressure call Aether, space or the void,
These 2 objects will have an infinite pressure point from all directions, except form between each other, Because there will only be a finite amount of pressure between 2 objects,
This low pressure point between 2 objects will cause them to accelerate towards one another, or better put towards the lowest pressure point between each other, As they move towards each other, the pressure drops, lower and lower, which is the cause of acceleration, The low pressure points between two objects is also in truth a black hole, It isn’t a hole, just a low pressure point. Between every Physical object, small or big, is a finite Low pressure point, now imagine a galaxy with millions of stars and planets and a low pressure point between every one of them, and in the center of this cluster will be the lowest pressure point called a black hole,That’s why you have a supermassive black hole in the center of every galaxy,

I personally think, that and it is not just a belief; it is a calculated thought, that our universe, is not physical at all, but it is a state of mind. It is a perception. Nothing physical is actually physical at all. Our universe Itself, does actually NOT exist on physical plane, although it is very convincing through our 5 senses that i does. I came up to this idea, as I was thinking about the size of the universe. That is also by the way why I said that it is somewhat calculated thought. The thought about the physical size of universe is, that the universe cannot possibly have a physical size, at all; it is impossible!
Why, you ask?
The reason is that for any particular object under observation to be measured against its physical size, we have to determine its boundaries; its corners; the line which determines its confines; something that tells us that okay, let's say a box has 6 walls. Each of the wall has an ending point where its last atoms will be occupying the physical space of the box. After which, there will be no more atoms of that box, but just air. So there is a line, a wall, a boundary of any kind or state of matter; be it liquid and solid boundary, as in beach and sand. Or be it water sprinkled in air. Every water drop has its boundary until the surrounding air starts.

The universe my friend, cannot possibly has a boundary. Let us assume for a second that it does have a boundary, be it in the plasma, solid, gaseous or liquid state; There will always be something outside of that boundary/wall/line.
Let's go another step further, assuming even one more thing that the boundary is a loop, like our Earth (which seems straight by our 5 senses but is actually round, and we cannot escape due to its very round nature, gravity and atmosphere and many other factors), even in that very case, if we are in a whirlpool kind of swirling medium which confines the universe, still there universe will not end there. Because there will always be something outside of this swirling, captivating, encompassing, confining medium...
So we start walking in the right dimension, (e.g. going upper direction on earth) the physical space is infinite. After the farthest galaxy we will find 1 billion years later, and even after our existence, there will always be something next to it.
It simply means, that it is not the physical space that exists; it is the perception of it which does!

Noi sapiamo che se immergiamo una canna in una vasca d'acqua la canna ci appare spezzata. Questo accade per via della differente densità dei mezzi in cui si trova la canna ovvero l'aria e l'acqua. Poiché in questi mezzi di diversa densità la luce si muove a differenti velocità in conseguenza del quale abbiamo un fenomeno di rifrazione e quindi noi percepiamo la canna come se fosse spezzata. La differenza di densità dell'aria e delle micro goccie d'acqua in sospensione è anche causa dell'arcobaleno che è esso stesso un altra manifestazione del fenomeno ottico di rifrazione della luce.
Ora se noi guardiamo a grandi distanze ad esempio da una montagna verso un'altra montagna vediamo che il grande numero degli strati di aria che si susseguono rendono la montagna lontana di colore diverso rispetto a quello che è in natura: tendiamo infatti a vedere le cose molto lontane di un colore bluastro.
Le lenti di vetro o cristallo modificano la direzione della luce sempre in base alla diversa densità della lente rispetto all'aria che le circonda e la luce passando da un mezzo (aria) all'altro (lente) modifica la sua direzione di conseguenza.
Spostiamoci ora nello spazio. Qui abbiamo distanze enormi di "vuoto cosmico". Ma nel vuoto cosmico non vi è un vuoto assoluto e totale: vi sono rari atomi e pulviscolo spaziale di dimensioni variabili. Con le grandi distanze cosmiche è possibile che il susseguirsi di strati dopo strati dopo strati... di questo mezzo composto da atomi e pulviscolo spaziale ecc. di spessore crescente viste le enormi distanze agisca un po' come agisce l'atmosfera, l'acqua, il vetro, il cristallo, ecc. quando viene attraversata dalla luce andando quindi a generare un effetto ottico e non gravitazionale? I have said this before: we need to be careful when taking measurements in severely warped space because the results might not be what they seem. This is especially true when measuring a black hole where those measurements become a mathematical catastrophe. One good example is the Schwarzschild radius, and for that matter, any other measurements of a black hole.

The very nature of a singularity is not a Planck length. It is zero. And it's not just zero, but also infinity. The image of the Messier 87 black hole gives us visual evidence of both the zero nature and infinite nature of the singularity. The image illustrates how space became so infinitely warped, that space warped inward on itself and became inverted inside out. In this image, the dark region of the black hole is no longer warped space, but rather inverted space. So things that once appeared to be small now begin to appear large, and things that once appeared large now begin to appear small.

This inversion means there is no singularity at the center of the black hole. Instead, the zero-point singularity has now become the outer circumference of the dark region of the black hole, and the dark region of the black hole has become inverted space. To properly measure inside a black hole, you would begin at the circumference of the black hole, the singularity. All points along the circumference are the same zero-point, the singularity. Then you would begin to measure inward toward the center. As you approach the center, your measurement begins to approach infinity. That's how you measure inside a black hole.

The realities of zero and infinity can be mind bending. Look it this way, when you look inside a black hole, you are getting a glimpse into a new infinite region, likely another universe just like ours – a zero dimensional universe where it's zero-size has become inverted into an infinite size.

I contend the singularity is what gave stability and form to our young galaxy. If the singularity had a one directional rotation, then it would likely spin around in circles and bash into everything. For this reason, I contend the poles of a galactic singularity should rotate in opposite directions. It is what would give stability to the singularity. This why I contend a side view of a black hole should appear more like a figure eight.

This made me think about light protons more. Then I started wondering... if a proton emits from its source, and never actually contacts matter as it travels through the universe, does it even exist? Lol, like the tree falling the woods, in a weird way, protons have to intersect or interact with something to have any practical existence. Kind of weird to think about. I’m making some assumptions here. One is that, if the universe expands faster than a proton can ever reach something material, then is it literally stuck in an infinitely non-existent state? I suppose that would also be under the assumption that the universe could possibly expand infinitely but I’d imagine that is unlikely. It’s a weird thought that vision is the result of, among other things, the end of a protons journey. In a weird way, some of those protons are very special. Whenever you look up into the sky, and see a distant point of light, you can think of how those particular protons that may have began their journey many years ago, crossed vast distances in space, just to get to you, your eye. If you’re the sentimental type, you might even think they were tailor made just for your eyes only. The further away they began their journey, the more impressive the idea even. I've often wondered what, if anything a black hole leaves behind.
Is the singularity just all the matter elements and energy the black hole absorbed compressed into single form?
Does it continue to fall through space even after the spirally swishy lights have disappeared?
Could that singularity be absorbed by another Black hole, smooching them together?
Imagine an entire galaxy compressed into a single point.
Imagine All galaxies compressed into single points.
Imagine if they collided together one piece at a time. The destiny and mass perhaps creating the last black hole.
The remaining singularities. Any any molecules or atoms that happen to be out there have no where to hide now because the gravity well of all reality is a single point now. A sheer drop into everything.

Here's the kicker.
What happens if you suck the contents out of an 'empty' plastic bottle? It collapses in on itself.
So if the universe can expand, can it contract? Could the combined mass and pull over Every little thing pull the boundaries of this universe right back home?
And when it does, when the walls of reality touch the event horizon.
All the energy in all the universe. All the things in the universe. All the power in the universe.

What if in that moment, it's all released again? Everything is thrown out to become new worlds, new stars, new galaxies, and the universe begins expanding all over again.

I think a dark matter is formed when it
leaves from the earth with very high speed in many astronomical environments,
because the frequency of incident photons from the earth side decrease after
collision with that matter by the Compton scattering. And as its speed
increases, scattered photons are below the detectable frequency. This results
in the dark matter when we see it from the earth. Also the famous black hole
picture is formed when incident photons from both the earth side and backside
of that matter collide with it which is leaving from the earth with very fast
speed, because the frequency of incident photons from the backside increases
after collision by the inverse Compton scattering.　Please see my upload "Compton scattering causes Dark matter,

I call this Hawking radiation paradox: If time runs faster outside the event horizon of a black hole than it does inside the black hole, Hawking radiation would evaporate the black hole before enough time has passed inside the black hole for such an event to have occurred. So how is it that a black hole could experience two frames of reference at the same time? There seems to be a real paradox here. If an observer inside a black hole looking out could survive long enough, could she witness hawking radiation evaporate the black hole before enough time in her frame of reference passed for the evaporation to occur?

Ever wonder why there is so much activity involved within the event horizon? There is a fascinating new hypothesis about the composition of the black hole and the inner workings of the event horizon. First alternative premise being that although black holes are measured in terms of stellar mass, due to their size and their field of gravitational acceleration,  they do not actually maintain any positive density mass, like baryonic matter. Black holes do not swallow, consume, or even pull in positive density mass beyond he event horizon. So how do black holes manage to exhibit a field of gravitational acceleration so strong that no mass particles, or even electromagnetic radiation such as light, can escape from it?The answer is better understood by thinking about gravity a bit differently. In fact, one actually has to reimagine the universe from its perspective make up. Considering the current notion the standard model of cosmology, the current measurements decompose the total energy of the observable universe with 68% dark energy, 27% mass–energy via dark matter, and 5% mass-energy via baryonic matter. So, as black holes are significantly more energy dense than ordinary matter, it would then make more sense that black holes are a product of dark matter rather than condensed ordinary matter.This requires that we rethink these internal relationships for total energy. Considering the 'Big Bang' theory, try thinking of the proposed one dimensional template for the pre-existing fabric of space-time without any real matter, rather than a singular point as modeled after a gravitational singularity. Then start unfolding it into existence; first into two dimensional space-time, which is an expansion from our one dimensional space-time, and then into a three dimensional space-time and so on. The expectation is that baryonic matter creation took place within a pre-existing medium of dark energy. Indeed, the existence of baryonic matter only warps the pre-existing fabric of space-time. Take away the positive density matter and you would still have a vessel in which the matter once existed. Wherein the creation of baryonic matter induces a displacement in the dark energy medium of the space-time fabric. This displacement can then be known as dark matter, the complement of baryonic matter, and it would appear that it provides baryonic matter with the ability to interact, bond, and evolve.Therefore, if the black holes are nothing but dark matter, it would also follow that dark matter can be accumulated, separate of baryonic matter. It would also follow that the gravitational force is more representative of dark matter than baryonic matter. Upon this hypothesis then, one can expect that there is a require transition to separate baryonic matter from its complementary dark matter.It starts first with the disintegration of matter as it interacts with the event horizon of the black hole. As mass is squeezed upon its own gravitational acceleration toward the black hole, liken to the spaghettification effect, its matter changes to allow for its disintegration via transmutation and the massive release of photons due to alpha decay and beta decay. This is the effect wherein mass is collected within the event horizon, into a plasma, increasing its photon density. The effect is like squeezing out the dark matter from mass, allowing for the baryonic matter to be reduced to its smallest constituent components. The dark matter is then absorbed into the black hole, and the remnants of baryonic matter are discarded and radiated out at high velocity back into the cosmos.If you're interested in exploring this concept more, please review the alternative theories presented in the book, 'The Evolutioning of Creation: Volume 2', or even the ramifications of these concepts in the sci-fi fantasy adventure, 'Shadow-Forge Revelations'. And in another theory, light travels along the space time fabric that warps around the black-hole. It doesn't actually fall into the black hole. It required social and public funding to liberate science from the boundaries/fetters of profit. Or it would not have happened. Nor could it have happened without profound international coordination (including with Russians and Chinese scientists!)

You see what I'm getting at.

While we can take pictures of previously unseeable things, 55 million light years away, global capitalism can't figure out how to get all the abundance of food into the world's hungry bellies, all the homeless into the empty homes, and how to guarantee the conditions of existence as social rights. Because there's no profit to be made there -- quite the contrary. Our economies are bound by the profit motive and the systems of production, distribution, research and technology are controlled by corporations. So these massive social problems are widely considered natural, permanent, unsolvable. The UN declared them as Millennial Development Goals to be reached by 2015. All the countries signed up; they had celebrations and press conferences. But they failed to reach them. The people remained hungry. The rich got richer. All because of the boundaries of the profit system.

Albert Einstein, whose theory of general relativity led to the theory of black holes -- as the only way to resolve otherwise unresolvable physics problems — was also a socialist. He saw then, a full century ago, that there was more than enough for humanity to provide for the needs of the people if the economy were simply reorganized. A century later the black hole theory has entered into the world of reality, while his plain observation that we can have a world without hunger, homelessness and poverty remains "theoretical."

That theory too can be made real. The scientists who made this breakthrough did so because they devoted their lives to it; it was not a passing interest that they focused on here and there. It will take a lot of dedication, hard work, trial, error and sacrifice to make our next, great collective "breakthrough for humanity." No one needs an advanced degree to join. Does this video really help to educate people about general relativity or spacetime, or does it just make people think they know what it's about?

In the two courses I took on spacetime and general relativity, my physics prof gave some very compelling arguments regarding the right ways to conceptualize the meaning of general relativity, as well as common misconceptions held even by some physicists. He also taught it in a way which started with the conceptual problems with how to explain the evidence, and without starting with that, I think it's hard to really explain spacetime or relativistic effects to anybody, or at least that's how it seems based on my admittedly amateur level of understanding which is very dependent upon having not been misled by my prof. He has a PhD in physics and another one in philosophy of science, and he's written an entire book about it titled "Relativity and the Nature of Spacetime". His name is Dr. Vesselin Petkov, and I highly recommend that you check it out if you want to know more about his arguments or explanations.

Nothing else I've ever seen even comes close to explaining it as well as the way this prof explained it, and from what I remember, the book was pretty good at it too. It also raises some crazy and interesting philosophical questions.

What you can see (maybe) is it's accretion disk, event horizon.

The actual dimensions of a black hole singularity are: 0 (width), 0 (height), & 0 circumference, all while containing the mass (& gravitational attractiveness) of one or more stars.

Technically GR only predicts what the object will look like from the outside, and how other matter will interact with it.  It cannot predict what happens beneath the event horizon.  Because there is no such thing as a singularity, or infinite gravity.  Quantum mechanics does not allow it, because a particle cannot inhabit a space smaller than its wavelength.  To find out what happens beneath the event horizon, we need a theory of quantum gravity.  M theory has made some strides in this regard - look up "fuzzball".  So GR predicting the object is fine - we know the objects exist.  But just because we see them and they appear to us the way GR predicts does not mean singularities are confirmed.

A technical comment: neither the M87 black hole nor the Sgr A* black hole have a classical accretion disc.  These are only found around high-accretion-rate active galactic nuclei (what are know as "thermal AGNs" because the energy come out in thermal emission from the hot opaque accretion disc).  The M87 and Sgr A* black holes are examples of low-accretion rate active galactic nuclei.  These are know as "non-thermal AGNs" because the energy output is dominate by mechanical energy in the radio jets.  The Event Horizon Telescope observes only radio waves and if there were a classical accretion disc around M87 it would not be emitting radio waves.  The description in the video of the light bending is good, but what is being bent is the RADIO emission.  The radio emission from around black holes is much more more poorly understood than the emission from classical accretion discs around high-accretion-rate AGNs. 6000 years ago, light from the earth headed towards a black hole (3000 light years away)
3000 years ago, some of that light arrived at the 2.6r horizon, did 1/2 an orbit, and was redirected BACK AT EARTH
Today, some of that light arrived back at earth.
If we could sort out those photons: WE COULD TAKE A 6000 YEAR OLD PICTURE of earth.

3000 years ago, some of those photons did 2, 3, 4, etc....orbits around the black hole before being redirected back at earth...
Today, we could take a picture of earth from ANY time in the past greater than 6000 years.

Granted, sorting it all out would be kinda hard. (Major understatement.) As well, the resolution would be terrible (not many photons to work with).
Other black holes are doing the same thing. Lots of them.
So, the FURTHER into the past, the BETTER picture of earth we could get.

I'm by no means an expert on the topic, and I understand this comment is probably going to go ignored, but there's something that has always bugged me about the notion of matter crossing the event horizon. In special relativity, the Lorentz factor (and therefore time dilation) is asymptotic as the velocity of a particle or system approaches the speed of light (one second to something traveling 99% the speed of light would be 7 seconds to us, and if it's going at 99.9% the speed of light, one of its seconds would be 21 seconds of ours or something like that, and the number just keeps shooting up). So to a photon's perspective, the moment it's created and the moment it hits matter light years away is the exact same instant. If gravitational time dilaton works in the same manner approaching the event horizon of a black hole, would that matter not experience the same thing? I've heard that this is the case, but then comes what I feel is the logical extension of this, which confuses me - suppose I could somehow reach the event horizon and still be alive. I would never experience crossing the event horizon, because to be at that same distance from the center, one of my seconds would be an "infinite" number of seconds - as in way more than enough time for the black hole to radiate away a bit (I mean, it would be enough time to immediately witness the universe reaching a point where time has no meaning if it were truly infinite ). So theoretically, to my perspective (in my interpretation, at least), would I not essentially just be approaching, but never reaching, the event horizon as it recedes and recedes until the black hole has fully radiated away? To say I reach a point in space where, even for a billionth of a second, the passage of time is infinitely fast, means that the exact moment I reach it, any inconceivable amount of time passes in less than the blink of an eye. "Infinite" is infinite ... it wouldn't matter how momentary my stay is there, it could be a Planck time, I would conceivably watch the effective "end" of the universe and beyond if I looked behind me and if black holes didn't actually ever radiate away. I mean, I get that black holes actually do absorb matter in reality, but what makes up for this discrepancy? Is this just a misinterpretation of mine? Wouldn't it be impossible for me to actually reach and cross the event horizon in a finite amount of time? Is that why it's said that the entropy of a black hole is its surface area, because information can't really get past the surface?

Excellent breakdown. So much so that it helped understand how gravitational lensing works. https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/03/Black_hole_lensing_web.gif

I am a VFX artist and I worked at the company that made the VFX for Interstellar many years ago. Double Negative.
Paul Franklin ( https://www.facebook.com/paul.franklin1 ) was the visual effects Supervisor for the movie, and the creative director of the company, and he was my boss there .I worked for him years before they won the Oscar for that movie.

Back then they created a special render engine that can calculate the bending of light around black holes, using the equations provided by Kip Thorne. As you ight know, is the engine with which they created the iconic BH images of the film.

I suggested to Paul, half joking, via Facebook, that they at Dneg could re ignite that render engine to create a new image of the recently discovered black hole, but, obviously, nicer and at a much higher resolution. As the new black is different, they would need to do a new image to better match the features of the new BH, but with both scientific accurary and artistic sense . I think it would be a beautifult idea, that I would need you to join the cause and make them excited about it, so they put some time and effort on it?

"All of the world lines end up at the center of the a black hole, in the singularity." Not if it is a rotating (kerr) black hole.

Firstly, a rotating black hole has two event horizons, an inner and an outer. Secondly, a rotating black hole has a ring singularity. Once crossing the inner event horizon, a traveler theoretically may steer away from the ring singularity, and may potentially end up in another universe or travel great distance through a wormhole. Google kerr penrose diagram.

Acceation disks are created because of relativistic frame dragging from a black holes angular momentum.
Eureka!!!

Understand first that it isn't a picture of a black hole, it is a picture of something we cannot detect surrounded by a bright region. There are MANY things in space that we cannot detect.

There are several problems here with the first being that NOTHING can stay "at the center of" a spiral galaxy. All the gravity is pointing outwards not inwards, the gradient is unbelievably intense and the time dilation effects of Einsteinian curvature mean that even basic physics becomes diffracted. There have been series of photographs before showing stars moving around unpredictably near the center of galaxies and there is already a supermassive structure in effect at those locations - the galaxy itself.

Second problem is that the moment you apply a force too strong for light to escape you have also created something that cannot itself move forward in time. Again Einstein wins and at best you can say "something such-n-so used to be there" but the object literally stops moving in spacetime the moment it happens.

Third and most simple, if we're looking directly at the core of a central galaxy jet of matter and particles, the actual center part is - axially - not going to be visible to optical equipment at any wavelength but WILL be physically there blocking and disrupting all energies that ARE detectable in that specific region... its like trying to see a fire from directly above through it's plume of black smoke - you simply cannot see the flames through the cloud.

So the picture they show is 100% confirmation bias without any science to back it up and NO attempt to validate.

Not to mention you can't have black holes in a big-bang universe for the simple reason that they instantly cease to exist if they try to form or the universe never began at all.

So we're looking at a hole... in the middle of a giant supermassive object which has a hole in the middle of it. The galaxy itself is sufficient to explain the image... and isn't going to tolerate a small massive gravitational source trying to occupy the locus of it's own inverse event horizon (the area in which all gravity is pulling outwards... we have one in Earth that follows the moon around the mathematical center of the planet kneeding the core and generating heat).

My own conclusion for the upper given question...
- We are able to see the object in the real world because the (straight) light rays reflect from the object, and our eyes catch those. Imagine two person of same height standing on each side of the wall, the height of wall is double the height of person. Now obviously they can't see each other because light can't bend, but they can hear each other if one of them shouts, because sound can bend(Diffraction/Interference). So MAYBE we are able to see the back side of black hole because the light from there isn't going straight but its bending ! But then too the question pops up that, the light after bending isn't coming towards us, then how did we detect that light ?

5:48 Now it got me thinking. The "shadow" that we will be able to see is composed of infinite repetitions of the event horizon. So, near the edge of the shadow, we'll see many instances of it in a small area of the image.
I'm thinking about Hawking radiation. if it loops around many times before going to infinity, maybe it can merge with other instances of Hawking radiation, possibly increasing the frequency (thus decreasing the wavelength), and achieving wavelengths like visible and gamma. Is it possible that we see light inside the shadow area? I'm thinking of a gradient that gets exponentially hotter and brighter as we look closer to the edge. This light, if I'm right, would represent pure, visible, Hawking radiation. Exclusively that, because there's no other known source of radiation coming from an event horizon.

So, if light that's less than 2.6 Schwarzschild radii is equally doomed to fall into the black hole as light travelling directly towards the singularity, why isn't 2.6 Schwarzschild the actual event horizon? Since light is traveling at the fastest possible speed, it's not like any external force could be applied to free it.

My only guess is that, were some light to be fired away from the singularity from a point less than 2.6 Schwarzschild radii (but more than 1) from it, there technically exists at least one world line that allows it to eventually escape. This would be true as long as the light is any distance (more than 1 radii) away from the event horizon, though the closer to that horizon that you get, the fewer worldlines there are that allow that escape and the more perpendicular they are to the horizon, so technically that's why 2.6 Schwarzschild isn't the event horizon. I actually do have some questions that could be answered
(1) Spectroscopy of accreting BHs: what causes emissions at different wavelengths? It is usually explained that synchrodron radiation causes X-ray emissions but isn't there emission in other wavelegths? I'd expect some thermal UV radiation, radiation from occasional collisions, mass differentiation of infalling / orbiting material adding structure to the disc etc... What causes the radio emissions?
(2) Materials that are nudged from the accretion disc enter unstable orbits, and so should be scattered in all directions. Will this not create some back-reaction onto the accretion disc itself, as scattered particles collide into those of the accretion disc?
(3) Further on particles that have unstable orbits, wouldn't there be violent collisions in this region? Could that not generate some particle creation (and further decay) leading to radiation in escape trajectories in a sphere around the BH? In the simplest case that would result in the entire BH being shrouded in by a shell of light (although due to the mechanism of its production I wouldn't expect it to be very bright - the wavelength of this emission would also matter).
(4) What are the possible stable geometries of accretion discs?
EDIT
(5) Will it ever be possible to observe a stellar ocultation by the SMBH (or even any other stellar BH) - if yes that would be exciting! I'm surprised that this hasn't happened already TBH.

No light goes in a straight line, because all light is sensitive to gravitational fields, even though it has no mass - because it still has energy. Karl Schwarzschild solved Einstein's equations for a sphereically-symmetric mass while on the Russian front during World War 1. He was in correspondence with Einstein, who wrote:

"I have read your paper with the utmost interest. I had not expected that one could formulate the exact solution of the problem in such a simple way. I liked very much your mathematical treatment of the subject."

Karl Schwarzschild died of disease during the war. His son became a prominent astrophysicist himself.

Question about the Schwarzschild radius and the stable orbit for light;

So, the Schwarzschild radius is effectively the radius of the event horizon, which is the point from which light cannot escape. If I understand the video correctly, the stable orbit for light was at 1.5r. In other words, if a photon crosses that 1.5r threshold, is it possible for that photon to escape off to infinity?
If it's not possible, then how come this 1.5r isn't where the event horizon lies? If the event horizon is the point from which light cannot escape, and light crossing the 1.5r threshold is destined towards the singularity, then it seems like 1.5r should be where the event horizon really exists.

The creative application of scientific principles to design or develop structures, machines, apparatus, or manufacturing processes, or works utilizing them singly or in combination; or to construct or operate the same with full cognizance of their design; or to forecast their behavior under specific operating conditions; all as respects an intended function, economics of operation and safety to life and property

NOTE: Gravity's strength is depended on surface area, not distance. Even though there are mentions of distance in terms of Schwarzschild radii. the actual calculations should be based on the formula of 4πr² which gives the surface area of a sphere.
example: Everything on the surface of the sphere with radius "r" experiences the same gravitational strength. and also. A sphere with radius 2r, will have a surface area which is 4 times larger than the base sphere. MEANING: The amount of gravity will be 4 times weaker! WHILE the distance has only doubled.

The image will be of Earth 50,000 years ago. Explanation: Some light from Earth from about 25,000 years ago will currently be arriving at the 2.6 radii of the black hole, where it will loop around the back, do 1/2 orbit, and be sent back towards Earth. Light that left Earth 50,000 years ago is currently arriving again at our location, after completing the return journey. So the image will at least partly be of Earth 50,000 years ago.

No, the boundary of the black circle you see is the photon sphere itself. You're seeing it magnified through a gravitational lens, but that's still the photon sphere, the closest a photon can pass it by and then escape again. It doesn't make it any less the photon sphere, it doesn't make it anything else, just because it appears bigger than it is. And no you don't see the event horizon, nothing you see when looking at a black hole is mapped to anything on the surface of its event horizon, or anything inside the photon sphere.

Very good explanation. But I have a couple of questions. You mention early in the video that light has no mass, and that that is why the accretion disk exists.
But if light has no mass, then why would the gravity of the black hole have any effect whatsoever?
And if light has no mass, why would it bend when it passes near anything that has mass, and particularly when it passes over a black hole.
In fact, if light has no mass, why can not even light captured by a black hole be stuck in it?
And if a black hole can capture something with no mass, and keep it forever, then there must be some "force" - let's call it gravity - that must be so powerful, that it prevents even the escape of light. So, if that force is so powerful - even at the event horizon - wouldn't it get stronger as whatever it has captured gets closer to its center? And if it gets stronger, stronger, why, then wouldn't any light it has captured "speed-up" as it gets closer to the center? And wouldn't that mean that light that has been captured by a black hole, and is headed towards its center, be moving faster than light that that has just entered the event horizon?
Isn't the speed of light a constant?
And, if the speed of of light is a constant - commonly expressed (oddly enough) in miles-pre-second, and if shortest distance between two points is space is a straight line, and light "bends" when it passes a massive object, then the light that didn't have to bend will reach a particular point in space sooner than light that had to "bend" on its journey to that particular point in space.
And doesn't that mean that the light that had to bend must reach that particular point in space LATER than the light that didn't have to bend. Right?
But then my question is: If light has no mass, why would it bend at all? Why wouldn't light that "hits" a massive object simply be reflected in a direction Away from that object, and light that does not hit it can then continue on its merry way?
That was my first question.
The second is: Why is whatever composes the "accretion disk" a disk at all?
Why wouldn't stuff that has not yet reached the event horizon described as a forming a disk rather than being described as a sphere that completely surrounds the black hole just beyond the event horizon?
If it is, in actuality, a disk, how thich is the disk? How wide? And why would stuff go closer to, and be captured by, the event horizon?
And if some of the accretion disk gets "caught" inside the event horizon, is the space that got caught replaced by the same amount of stuff from somewher else?
And does the disk revolve around the black hole, just outside of its grasp; or is it in - for lack of a better word - in some sort of geostationary orbit?
If it's the former; why?
If it's the latter; why?
If it's neither, what is it?
And why?

These questions are sincere.
I've thought about this kind of stuff since I was a kid.
Now, I'm just a retired Judge with more questions than answers.

Joseph J. Romano, JMC (Ret'd)
JRomano@Protonmail.com

There's no such thing as a black hole.  Hilbert's erroneous derivations of the field equations are what make it possible for it to even mathematically exist in the first place.  Special relativity forbids infinite point mass particles.  There is absolutely no reason to assume such a preposterous entity exists when alternative explanations can much more readily explain the observed confluences of energy in space without resorting to division by zero, such as described by Alfven and Peratt.

You said that even radially directed light can't escape. That is not plausible with modern physics I think. Waves bend sharply around when they have the slightest inclination. The reason is mass related time dilation. When a wave is perfectly radial and won't bend around it will never fall into the center because a slower time never leads to a reversing. Going backwards would imply time travel backwards in time from our point of reference. The light wave is escaping but it is frozen in time. Also the wave is still traveling at the speed  of light albeit that the wave is not only frozen by time dilation but also by it's own waves it creates by passing that much matter (''slow light").

Ok, I have two questions relating to black holes that have been on my mind for a while.

1. If you were to cross the event horizon, would you see a sudden flash of light? My thinking is that as matter falls into the black hole some of the light would be emitted directly perpendicular to the center at just the right time to effectively become 'stuck' on the event horizon, perpetually trying to escape. In which case, all the matter which has previously fallen in would create a layer of light which one could conceivably pass and observe.

2. If you were to look outwards from a black hole after falling in, again, would you see a sudden flash of light? My thinking this time is that since time passes slower the closer one is to the center of a black hole, looking outwards the universe will appear to progressively speed up. In which case, the universe is emitting more light per second relative to your time. So the intensity of the light will increase the closer you get to the singularity as all the additional light from the sped up universe enters the black hole and catches up to your position, no?

3:21 An unstable orbit is not an orbit where the orbiting object eventually leaves the orbit. Even, if the orbit is unstable, objects might be trapped in there forever. Unstable just means that if you nudge an object in that orbit, it will not go back into its original orbit.
In short, "unstable" doesn't mean "will go away", but "doesn't come back"
The best example is (as always) a pendulum. Certainly you can make a pendulum stand upright, but it will fall down as soon as you nudge it just a little bit.

Hi Derek. I'm going to disagree with you, for once. With only my intuition working here, I don't think the accretion disk will be a flat disk, like a ring. As the matter within the accretion disk is going so fast, it's going to hit other bits of matter, causing them to explode or deflect each other. Probably more likely explode and vaporize. And an explosion wouldn't end up as a flat disk if it's going so fast. The inertia of the strike/explosion would cause the matter to go every which direction, including around and over the black hole or to the sides or diagonally, and would never settle into a ring-like accretion disk.
